definitions.definition: Of the same kind; alike , similar .
Having the same composition throughout; of uniform make-up.
In the same state of matter .

In any of several technical senses uniform ; scalable ; having its behavior or form determined by, or the same as, its behavior on or form at a smaller component (of its domain of definition, of itself, etc.).

subdefinitions.definition: Of polynomials , functions , equations , systems of equations, or linear maps : ( algebra , of a polynomial ) Such that all its nonzero terms have the same degree . ( linear algebra , by specialization , of a system of linear equations ) Such that all the constant terms are zero. ( mathematical analysis , generalizing the case of polynomial functions , of a function f {\displaystyle f} ) Such that if each of f {\displaystyle f} 's inputs are multiplied by the same scalar , f {\displaystyle f} 's output is multiplied by the same scalar to some fixed power (called the degree of homogeneity or degree of f {\displaystyle f} ). ( Formally and more generally , of a partial function f {\displaystyle f} between vector spaces whose domain is a linear cone ) Satisfying the equality f ( s x ) = s k f ( x ) {\displaystyle f(s\mathbf {x} )=s^{k}f(\mathbf {x} )} for some integer k {\displaystyle k} and for all x {\displaystyle \mathbf {x} } in the domain and s {\displaystyle s} scalars. In ordinary differential equations (by analogy with the case for polynomial and functional homogeneity): ( of a first-order differential equation ) Capable of being written in the form f ( x , y ) d y = g ( x , y ) d x {\displaystyle f(x,y)\mathop {dy} =g(x,y)\mathop {dx} } where f {\displaystyle f} and g {\displaystyle g} are homogeneous functions of the same degree as each other. ( of a linear differential equation ) Having its degree-zero term equal to zero; admitting the trivial solution. ( of a general differential equation ) Homogeneous as a function of the dependent variable and its derivatives.
examples: The function f ( x , y ) = x 2 + x 2 y + y 2 {\displaystyle f(x,y)=x^{2}+x^{2}y+y^{2}} is not homogeneous on all of R 2 {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{2}} because f ( 2 , 2 ) = 16 ≠ 2 k ∗ 3 = 2 k f ( 1 , 1 ) {\displaystyle f(2,2)=16\neq 2^{k}*3=2^{k}f(1,1)} for any k {\displaystyle k} , but f {\displaystyle f} is homogeneous on the subspace of R 2 {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{2}} spanned by ( 1 , 0 ) {\displaystyle (1,0)} because f ( α x , α y ) = α x 2 = α 2 f ( x , y ) {\displaystyle f(\alpha x,\alpha y)=\alpha x^{2}=\alpha ^{2}f(x,y)} for all ( x , y ) ∈ Span ⁡ { ( 1 , 0 ) } {\displaystyle (x,y)\in \operatorname {Span} \{(1,0)\}} .

subdefinitions.definition: In abstract algebra and geometry : ( ring theory , of an element of a graded ring ) Belonging to one of the summands of the grading ( if the ring is graded over the natural numbers and the element is in the k th summand, it is said to be homogeneous of degree k ; if the ring is graded over a commutative monoid I , and the element is an element of the i th summand, it is said to be of grade i ) ( of a linear map f {\displaystyle f} between vector spaces graded by a commutative monoid I {\displaystyle I} ) Which respects the grading of its domain and codomain. Formally: Satisfying f ( V j ) ⊆ W i + j {\displaystyle f(V_{j})\subseteq W_{i+j}} for fixed i {\displaystyle i} (called the degree or grade of f {\displaystyle f} ), V j {\displaystyle V_{j}} the j {\displaystyle j} th component of the grading of f {\displaystyle f} 's domain, W k {\displaystyle W_{k}} the k {\displaystyle k} th component of the grading of f {\displaystyle f} 's codomain, and + representing the monoid operation in I {\displaystyle I} . ( geometry , of a space equipped with a group action ) Informally : Everywhere the same, uniform, in the sense that any point can be moved to any other (via the group action) while respecting the structure of the space. Formally : Such that the group action is transitively and acts by automorphisms on the space (some authors also require that the action be faithful ). ( geometry ) Of or relating to homogeneous coordinates .

In miscellaneous other senses: ( probability theory , Fourier analysis , of a distribution S {\displaystyle S} on Euclidean n-space (or on R n ∖ { 0 } {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}\backslash \{\mathbf {0} \}} ) ) Informally : Determined by its restriction to the unit sphere. Formally : Such that, for all real t > 0 {\displaystyle t>0} and test functions ϕ ( x ) {\displaystyle \phi (\mathbf {x} )} , the equality S [ t − n ϕ ( x / t ) ] = t m S [ ϕ ( x ) ] {\displaystyle S[t^{-n}\phi (\mathbf {x} /t)]=t^{m}S[\phi (\mathbf {x} )]} holds for some fixed real or complex m {\displaystyle m} . ( set theory , order theory , of a relation ) Holding between a set and itself; being an endorelation .
